title: Fix the SPI alignment fix
body:
Hey I was working with SPI today while also tracking https://github.com/esp-rs/esp-hal/pull/395 and decided to test it but I think the implementation is not quite as intended. step_by always gives a multiple of your step-size so if your chunksize was 9 it will give 0,4,8, however in the match statement you'd match 1,1,1, instead of 0,0,1. This fixes that (although I think it can be optimized). 

To see the difference in action see: https://onlinegdb.com/23bFTBT6d

title: New releases for all HAL packages
Add RADIO peripheral

- Rework macros to allow non-pac peripheral structs

title: Fix direct boot linker script for ESP32-C2/C3
body:
Fixes #386 

This makes sure RWTEXT isn't overwritten by BSS

title: Fix hidden alignment requirement (SPI)
body:
Fixes #295 

While this obviously has a performance impact, it's surprising small.

main: 61.5 us
here: 68.25 us

(Release mode, ESP32-C3, boot-defaults)

Fixes
- the alignment requirement
- doesn't read past the chunk
- uses volatile writes to the fifo

title: Add support for 26Mhz xtal in ESP32-HAL
body:
Referencing Issue #329, these changes add support for 26Mhz crystals to be used with the ESP32.

These changes were made in reference to the changes in PR #301 where support was added for 26Mhz crystals for the ESP32c2 chip. As such the changes here were almost identical, I have tried to keep the same convention for the features to select between crystal varieties as in #301.

I have tested these changes with a Sparkfun ESP32 Thing (the same board as referenced in #329) using the example projects in [esp32-hal](https://github.com/esp-rs/esp-hal/tree/main/esp32-hal/examples) and while I am not able to test the projects with external devices such as those using i2c (as I do not have any sensors/devices to connect) all examples using the standalone esp32 seem to be working correctly. I also unfortunately do not own a 40Mhz esp32 to test these changes on (to ensure it still works), though the examples are being built without error.

Sorry if this PR doesn't follow convention, as this is my first. I'd love any feedback on things I can improve for next time!

title: Make sure to re-export xtensa-lx-rt
body: HAL users unfortunately might need things like `xtensa_lx_rt::interrupt::CpuInterruptLevel`, so re-export `xtensa-lx-rt`

title: Remove unnecessary `rt` crate dependencies
body:
Fixes #382 

- remove dependencies to `rt` crates and `riscv` / `xtensa-lx` from the chip specific HALs, re-export from esp-hal-common
- re-export `riscv` / `xtensa-lx` in the chip specific HALs
- `entry` is re-exported and added to the prelude
- atomic emulation is always included by the HAL for ESP32-S2 (like it's already the case for ESP32-C2 / ESP32-C3)

This PR looks huge but most of the changes are in the examples.

Nice side-effect: fixes #197 

This has some potential for bikeshedding about some names (e.g. `trapframe::TrapFrame`) - I tried to choose the names carefully but don't have strong opinions about them

_BEFORE_ merging this
- [x] publish a new `xtensa-lx-rt` version, probably also `xtensa-lx`
- [x] publish the PACs (with removed `rt` dependencies)
- [x] optionally wait for a new published `esp-backtrace`

This also bumps the versions of all contained crates

title: Fix (I2S) circular DMA
body:
Fixes #387 

Tested on all the targets - seems to fix the issue and doesn't cause side effects. Also we already do things differently depending on the fact it's a circular DMA transfer so this looks fine to me

title: Async SPI
body:
This PR implements a `Future` based abstraction around the current DMA implementations and uses said abstraction to implement the Async SPI traits from e-h on `SpiDma`.

FYI the diff looks kinda weird because of the fmt commit, perhaps compare the commits _before_ that fmt commit for easier viewing.

## Breaking changes

`dma::private`, `gdma::private`, and `pdma::private` no longer exist. All the DMA types/traits are now public. The ideal solution would be to erase these types see #381.

## Future work

- The error handling for the DMA needs some work at the moment DMA errors are unchecked.
- We could implement the e-h-a SPI traits on the normal `Spi` struct using the peripheral FIFO + interrupts, but this is less efficient and unnecessary for this initial implementation.

title: AnyPin
body:
This is not necessarily meant to get merged but we can if we agree it's a good idea

This adds an `ErasedPin` type by having an enum and using the enum-dispatch pattern.
The good thing is, it's easy to use this pattern also for other heavily typed types (e.g. SPI, I2C, I2S, ...) and doesn't need any refactoring of existing code. In other places we can even use an existing macro to implement `From` and `TryInto` - but all macros I found didn't support generics which we need for the mode.

It looks like a nice solution but maybe I forgot something that makes it actually a bad thing 🤷‍♂️ 

Closes https://github.com/esp-rs/esp-hal/issues/115
Closes https://github.com/esp-rs/esp-hal/issues/277

Allow Debug interrupts in Xtensa critical sections
body: Right now if you step into a critical section whilst debugging it will hang forever. This changes reduces the interrupt level down to 5, where level 6 is the debug interrupt on all our esp32 Xtensa-based chips.

title: Refactor `rtc_cntl` module and add `get_reset_reason` function
body:
I realize this is a bit of an odd PR on its own, but I am building towards some other more interesting work. This was pretty self-contained so I figured I'd just PR it now.

The `rtc_cntl` module is going to grow quite a bit, so I've pulled it into its own module directory. The `rtc` module followed it into this directory as well.

The `get_reset_reason` function is pretty simple and basically just maps a ROM function's return value to an enum, `SocResetReason`. There were a few variants which had conflicting values, so I have noted these in comments and, IMO, provided a reasonable workaround, at least for the time being.

title: Rework the CI workflow
body:
I've pretty much completely rewritten this workflow from scratch. Rather than the insane level of concurrency we were using before, this approach is much more tame. This should scale with regards to supporting new devices for the foreseeable future.

The run takes ~6 minutes on average with a cache hit, which is acceptable IMO. Once we update `xtensa-toolchain` to use `espup` this should hopefully help reduce the total runtime further.

We also no perform full builds for each image format to ensure that linker errors do not occur. Doing this already revealed an issue for `mcu-boot` (only on C3 currently) so this seems worthwhile. Examples are built using the same sets of features as they previously were.

Closes #258.

I haven't thoroughly tested everything, but it should still work.

title: pulse counter implementation
body:
This is complete. I implemented this following LEDC as a guide and I'm not completely happy with the resulting API.  Some possibilities:
- implement each unit as a peripheral (PCNT0, PCNT1 etc) and initialize the clock when the first unit is configured. This would eliminate the unit::Number which is confusing with channel::Number.
- don't put the channel implementation in a separate  module.
- don't make Channel an object and just have configure_channel(ch: Channel, config: ChannelConfig) as a method on the unit.

title: Support ESP32-C2 with 26MHz Xtal
body:
According to [ESP-IDF](https://docs.espressif.com/projects/esp-idf/en/release-v5.0/esp32c2/get-started/windows-setup.html#get-started-windows-first-steps:~:text=If%20IDF%20monitor%20fails%20shortly%20after%20the%20upload%2C%20or%2C%20if%20instead%20of%20the%20messages%20above%2C%20you%20see%20random%20garbage%20similar%20to%20what%20is%20given%20below%2C%20your%20board%20is%20likely%20using%20a%2026%20MHz%20crystal.%20Most%20development%20board%20designs%20use%2040%20MHz%2C%20so%20ESP%2DIDF%20uses%20this%20frequency%20as%20a%20default%20value.) most development boards use a 40MHz xtal but 26MHz are available so it makes sense to support it.

However, since 40MHz is also the default for ESP-IDF it's also the default for esp-hal.

I tested this on both, 40MHz and 26MHz versions and checked SPI, I2C and UART with a logic analyzer - looks good.

Please note: If you are using a 26MHz chip you need to supply a custom bootloader configured for 26MHz otherwise clock config will panic.

Also this changes the _run_ alias to include the `flash` command - since `espflash 2.0` RCs are available for some time now we should do that - also apparently I'm the only one using `cargo run`

title: PeripheralRef/spi
body:
The second driver to be converted to the new PeripheralRef format.

Hopefully, this should be a better reference than the first one which got a little messy.

title: Add a CI job to verify formatting
Fix LEDC duty-cycle updates
body:
Fixes https://github.com/esp-rs/esp-hal/issues/285.

Added `start_duty_without_fade!()` and `update_channel!()` to `set_duty!()` in order for the new duty-cycle to take effect.

`start_duty_without_fade!()` is a new macro that configures the fading register. It was found that setting `LEDC_DUTY_START_CHn` is required in order for the new duty-cycle to take effect. The other fields of the `conf1` are also written and configured for no fading.

For `cfg(esp32)` the `update_channel!()` macro now takes a speed argument, and will result in a no-op for high speed. Because high speed variant doesn't have the `para_up` field.

This PR also removes the restriction that `set_duty(0)` could not be called without error.

Tested on ESP32C3. Builds for ESP32.

title: GPIO module refactoring
body:
This started as an attempt to avoid pinning the `paste` dependency but ended up it a larger refactoring of the GPIO module

The only breaking change is that the `gpio::gpio_types` is now gone and the types are directly contained in `gpio`

- reduce the number of macros, no nested macros anymore
- remaining macros don't try to be clever
- should be easier to maintain and extend (hopefully)
- might be helpful for the larger GPIO rewrite (or might not - at least it doesn't make that more difficult and might give us more time there since necessary improvements are unblocked now)
- implementing things like type-erasure should be simpler now
- removes some unused confusing things (like many unused macro parameters)
- all the pins, dac and adc are now contained in esp-hal-common which might make some things easier (like defaults for `None` pins)

It's still far from perfect - especially `into_analog` isn't much improved.  Also, the file structure is a bit odd. However, this PR is already quite big and we can still improve things in future

title: Export InputSignal and OutputSignal
body:
In order to write something like [this](https://github.com/IsaacDynamo/esp32-c3-p1-bridge/blob/master/esp_buffered_serial/src/optional_pin.rs), `InputSignal` and `OutputSignal` need to be made public.

Can they be made public, or is there a good reason that they are currently not public?

title: Finalize I2S RX Implementation
body:
- handles incompletely filled DMA RX descriptor buffers
- uses fractional dividers to better match the given sample rate
- basic API documentation

title: Update install sections
body: - Update installation section to use `espup`

title: PeripheralRef init: uart
body:
* Add the Peripheral trait & PeripheralRef struct definitions
* Implements Peripheral for each chip UART peripherals (generated a new token which replaces the pac version)
* Renames Serial to Uart to be more in line with trm
* Refactor Uart to use the Peripheral trait constructor
* Refactor examples to use the new Uart driver & Peripherals struct 

This PR allows us to either pass in a mutable reference to a peripheral, which is automatically freed when the driver is dropped, or by value, see the following code snippet:

```rust
let mut uart0 = Uart::new(&mut uart);
writeln!(uart0, "Test 1").unwrap();
drop(uart0); // this ends the mutable borrow of uart, its now available in the peripheral struct again
let mut uart0 = Uart::new(uart); // construct via move this time
writeln!(uart0, "Test 2").unwrap();
```

title: Implemented ability to write bytes in `UsbSerialJtag`
Add Rx and interrupts to UsbSerialJtag
body:
This is a first cut of adding USB serial Rx and the ability to trigger interrupts when packets are received. I have attempted to make the interface as similar as possible to regular serial UART where it makes sense.
This does include a breaking change - now you actually have to create an instance of UsbSerialJtag with a peripheral instead of just using the registers directly.
I have updated the esp32c3 and esp32s3 examples to demonstrate some of the new features and tested the change on my ESP32-C3-DevKit-RUST-1. I don't have an esp32s3 handy to test its example, but it at least builds. Would appreciate if someone else could test it for me please.
To note:
- I have slightly changed the name of the Rx interrupt from "serial_out_recv_pkt" to "rx_packet_recv" because the TRM names them from the point of view of the USB host and I find it really confusing.

Possible future work:
- It looks like the esp32s3 has the ability to map the USB D+ and D- lines to arbitrary GPIO pins using the GPIO matrix. I don't have any way to test that so I've left it for now.
- I also didn't implement the Tx interrupt because I'm not sure of its utility.

Would love to hear if anyone has any useful feedback on this change.

title: Avoid potential linker error for ESP32-C2 and ESP32-C3
body:
It is possible that the linker places `abort` out of reach for the jump at https://github.com/rust-embedded/riscv-rt/blob/91d63a31173a5570a11fa3927de062638c73f050/asm.S#L102

This happened to me and this PR fixes that

title: Add more configuration symbols and simplify the build script
body:
I've added a number of new symbols here to hopefully make our code a bit easier to reason about. I've also changed our approach in the build script, where each chip just defines all of its symbols now. I think this will be easier to maintain.

I was careful when changing the `#[cfg]`s but it's always possible I've made a mistake, so @MabezDev @bjoernQ please double check my work if you could! I've also consolidated the `DmaPeripheral` enums, and again while I've already checked this please review it.

Not sure how many more symbols we can pull out right now, but if I've missed anything let me know!

title: Detangle I2C clock calculation
body:
- fixes ESP32-C2 in release mode
- fixes the MPU6050 init problem (i.e. no workarounds needed anymore)
- makes the I2C clock calculation code readable and easy to compare to ESP-IDF

Closes #230 
Fixes #213

title: Preliminary I2S Implementation
body:
This adds preliminary I2S support for ESP32, ESP32-S2, ESP32-C3 and ESP32-S3

There are quite a few things missing but since the PR is already quite big those can and should be tackled with separate PRs

Things to note here
- sample rate isn't exactly matched in most cases (needs fractional divider support)
- RX not tested with real I2S source (hope the I2S microphone will be in the mail this week)
- MCLK pin not available on ESP32
- only stereo supported for now
- on ESP32-S3 and ESP32-C3 one-shot reading doesn't seem to work in debug mode (needs further investigation) - seems like on ESP32-S3 the RX_DONE_INT never gets asserted after the first time and on ESP32-C3 it is immediately asserted (but only in debug? doesn't make too much sense to me)
- almost undocumented for now

Closes #247

title: Fix UART unlisten calls so they clear the interrupt enable
body:
The interrupt unlisten methods on `esp_hal_common::serial::Instance` are setting the interrupt enable bit instead of clearing it, so they do the same thing as the interrupt listen methods.
Tested using an ESP32. Verified that if I run
```
uart0.listen_rx_fifo_full();
uart0.unlisten_rx_fifo_full();
```
I still get interrupts. With my change, I stop getting interrupts.

title: doc: add `#[doc(inline)]` to esp-hal-common re-exports

title: MCPWM MVP implementation
body:
## Major things missing:

- [x] Need to resolve TODOs
- [x] Documentation
- [x] Test on ESP32 Hardware
- [x] Test on ESP32-S3 Hardware
- [ ] something else?

## Request for feedback:

### Are we allowed to copy text passages from the reference manuals for documentation? What about pictures?
The MCPWM peripheral is quite complex with lots of moving parts so adding some graphics might help.

### What are people thinking about the API design? 
I chose an implementation without looking much at the existing `LEDC` code or the ESP IDF API.
There might be some disconnect here.

Things I tried to consider were (in no particular order):
* compile errors over runtime errors
* "zero-cost"-ness
* use of const-generics with the option of using [adt_const_params](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/95174) at some later point
* ability to add more features later without major architectural changes
* discoverability

I'd love to have some feedback here whether these goal were accomplished and if other considerations were missed.

### What's the pwm period of a Count-Up-Down Mode timer?
~~The [docs ](https://www.espressif.com/sites/default/files/documentation/esp32-s3_technical_reference_manual_en.pdf) mention:~~
~~> The PWM timer starts increasing from zero until the period value is reached. Then, the timer decreases back to zero. This pattern is then repeated. The PWM period is the result of (the value of the period field × 2 + 1)~~

~~Looking at the timing diagrams is seems to me that it would rather be `period field × 2`. Is that a mistake in the docs?~~

Doing some measurements confirmed that the docs indeed are wrong here the period is `period field × 2`

body: This fixes #236 but doesn't contain any modification of the CI workflow to check the `direct-boot` feature
